The garden and its tea houses are not to be missed, plan a good 45 minutes to tour them in addition to the time in the museum proper.The Shang Bronzes on the 3rd floor are absolute treasures, and the museum has consistently good, interesting and well curated shows. Obviously the museum staff knows English well and signage on permanent and temporary exhibits is consistently good, accurate and informative.Combining this and the Ota Ukiyoue Museum will make for a very pleasant way to spend a day.The museum resturant is good, but nothing great. But a nice place for a cup of coffee and a sweet, particularly if there is a window seat available with a view of the garden.There is a viking buffet Riata near the Ota which has good food and is reasonably priced on weekdays, they raise the price for the same thing on weekends and holidays though.Enjoy.
superb museum at Omote Sando. This is a wonderful Japanese museum to visit again and again, and appreciate not only the exhibits but also the building itself and the adjacent garden.
Nezu Museum and Nezu Garden. The museum is beautiful but the park is really amazing, just walking there with family or friends make a nice day, we can see sometimes a tea ceremony .

Overrated. As other reviews have mentioned this museum has a beautiful garden and not a lot of exhibits. After only a half hour, my wife and I couldn't believe we had seen everything the Nezu had on display. We spent another 45 minutes walking through the beautiful gardens, but considering the number of public parks & gardens in & around Tokyo, the 1000 yen entrance fee was too expensive. In Jun 2012 the museum was showing 14-15th century tea ceremony pottery, a few bronze vases & statues, some tacky 19th century English clocks and a little art work. If the price were no more than 500 yen, I'd give it 4 stars, but for 1000 yen, I can't recommend it.

A nice private museum - but could do better. I enjoyed a nice pleasant hour of looking at the exhibits and strolling in the great Japanese garden. I love to spend hours in museums, but was disappointed a bit because they show so little of their large permanent collection. They could have built more rooms for exhibition instead of many teahouses in the garden, nice cafe or the hall on B1F. I would have easily given five stars if the person in charge were more keen on the idea that museums are meant to show and educate.I find it sad that many museums (or art in general) in Japan are privately owned and show only small part of the collection. Also, there is a bad tendency to invest money on building fancy galleries with no permanent collection- which is ridiculous, when there are enough such galleries existing. While the building of the Nezu Museum, or the Yamatane Museum not far away, are great, they could have put more emphasis on displaying their collections as much and as best as they can.

A Private Museum. Been to Tokyo many times but have not been to a private funded museum. This was a fabulous find. The walk from the subway station was quite long but enjoyable with the many shops and the street lined with azaleas which were in bloom. Seeing the works of art in the galleries was just about right that you didn't get bored. The outstanding feature was the Japanese garden with acres of walkways.

Hidden gem. The Nezu museum is a great find. It is definitely off the main tourist routes, to the point that many Tokyoites also are not that aware of it. The building was recently completely renovated and is set in a magnificent garden, which is reason enough to visit (there is also a tranquil new coffee shop with beautiful views).The museum is very central and easy to reach from Omotesando or Aoyama. It is rarely quiet and is a welcome escape from the hustle and bustle that surround it.

Museum is great but the garden is fabulous. You feel like you are in a private garden far from the city. Great place to wander for hours in spring. My favorite time to go is fall. The colours are amazing.

Gem of a museum with a beautiful garden. This is a lovely little gem of a museum specialising in Asian art and artefacts. Whilst the great majority of visitors seem to be Japanese, there are signs in English at the entry to each gallery  with an overview of the items on display. The museum itself is not huge, but there is a garden out the back that encourages exploration, with various tea houses, ponds, waterfall, shrines and centuries-old statues dotted alongside winding paths - it was a lovely way to spend a sunny afternoon. There is also a small cafe on the grounds that affords a beautiful view of the garden. If you have time, I would recommend a meal there. The prices seemed reasonable and we very much enjoyed our afternoon tea in the tranquil setting.  The cafe was also popular with other visitors, and a queue quickly developed soon after we were seated, but they didn't have to wait long for a table. Of note, too, is the walk to the museum from Omote-sando station. While the road itself, being not very wide nor shadowed by large buildings, has something of the feel of a backstreet, it is lined with big name stores (e.g. Prada, Cartier, Chloe, Issey Miyake) that quickly put paid to this impression. The Prada building was an architectural show-stopper, with bulging glass windows that covered the entire structure. I also loved the Japanese minimalist aesthetic and the interplay of concrete, wood and glass in the museum.

Doll Festival and Irises and Eight Bridges. Two great exhibits: the Hina Miniatures of Meiji Emperor and wife, royal characters, samurais and pesants are precious and the exhibit of Japanese painting from the Edo Period (Irises on gold background) is beautiful. Some poetry on caligraphy can be also seen.

oh oh oh. Our Japanese friends took us and we were totally wowed and charmed by the beautiful multi level gardens in the heart of the city as well as the lovely art work on display in the modern spacious museum. The cafe is a lovely space where we had a great lunch.

Hidden Tokyo- Romantic and Lovely Small Museum. I like to take special people to Nezu Museum. It is quiet- and a bit off the beaten track. You can easily walk there from Omotesando Crossing...down the wonderful shopping street featuring designers such as Yohji Yamamoto, Issey Miyake and Rei Kawakubo- and the stunning Prada building is an architectural wonder! You may enjoy lunch with a garden view at the museum. It is perhaps the most "Japanese" of the museums in Tokyo. It does not feature Western artwork like many of the National museums in Tokyo- whose cur

Often overlooked, but very Japanese experience. I had never even heard of this museum before until a visitor pointed it out to me raving about its charm. I finally checked it out and it was amazing. Try and go on a weekday and there will be few people. Probably only need to spend a couple of hours there but well worth it.

"New" Nezu museum - quite wonderful. This place has recently (Oct 09) re-opened after a long period shut for refurbishment. The museum itself is lovely - fairly small, with regularly-changing exhibits. Everything's clearly labelled in English as well as Japanese, and the place is beautiful: a great example of how museums should exhibit their treasures.On its own, I'd probably give the museum three or four stars. But what makes the Nezu institute so special is the quite, quite wonderful garden. You can comfortably lose yourself amidst the tree-lined paths for half an hour or more, and it's truly beautiful. Quite unexpectedly, this place turned out to be one of the highlights of our Japanese trip: a real hidden gem, and very highly recommended.
